I.  THE PROPOSAL 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed 
multitranche financing facility (MFF) to the Islamic Republic of Afghanistan for the Transport 
Network Development Investment Program.1  
II.  THE INVESTMENT PROGRAM 
A.  Rationale 
2.  The  proposed  investment  program  will  rehabilitate  and  expand  major  sections  of 
Afghanistan’s road and railway networks. The investments, physical and nonphysical in nature, 
will add to those already being supported by the Asian Development Bank (ADB) and other 
development partners. The aim is to further improve domestic and regional connectivity while 
widening access to social and economic opportunities. The effort will facilitate investment into 
key strategic industries, including mining and related services. The result will be growth, jobs, 
welfare and trade. Providing better links from Central Asia to markets in the south, east, and 
west  will  generate  transit  fees  but  also  new  business  opportunities  to  companies  across 
Afghanistan. The road network is incomplete, mostly in bad shape, and the railway network is in 
its infancy. Capital outlays in both networks will cut transport costs, increase competitiveness, 
and  raise  productivity.  A  modern  and  efficient  multimode  system  reduces  poverty,  and 
contributes to inclusive economic growth and stability. 
3.  Roads serve 90% of Afghanistan’s travel demand. The network is overstretched while 
vehicles numbers are rising fast. Since 2009, there are 23% more cars, 15% more trucks, 48% 
more motorcycles, and 2% more buses on the roads. Freight is carried mainly in private trucks 
since rail transport is too new and limited and air transport is too expensive. More than 85% of 
roads are in poor condition, with large portions, particularly in rural areas, impassable. Only 15% 
of planned national highways have been built. The investment program will invest in almost  
600 km of roads, or 7% of the total national and regional highway network.  
4.  Afghanistan needs railways for development. Its strategic location and recent finds of 
mineral and ore deposits add to railway relevance. Less than 100 kilometers (km) of track have 
been built so far. This includes the 75 km railway line constructed between Hairatan and Mazar-
e-Sharif (Railway Project), a project completed in 2011 with ADB funding.2 This is the first rail 
project in Afghanistan’s history. To be viable, the network must grow. Future expansion plans 
include a new section from Mazar-e-Sharif to Bamyan to the newly discovered mineral centers.3  
Other sections will link Mazar-e-Sharif to Andkhoy in the northwest, and eventually run from 
Andkhoy to Herat. Sections from Iran to Herat and Kandahar to Spin Boldak are also under 
consideration. The entire network will be based on the Central Asian gauge system. This will 
make the railway relevant and competitive, and facilitate north-south trade. Central Asia is a 
conduit for mineral exporters who will rely on Afghanistan’s railway network. 
5.  The road subsector faces four main problems: (i) a small network in a poor state of 
repair,  (ii)  weak  institutional  capacity,  (iii) lack  of  quality  contractors  and  consultants,  and         
(iv) limited construction materials. Together with insecurity, these bottlenecks lead to higher 
than average construction and maintenance costs. They also affect timelines for construction.4 
Despite this, ADB projects are experiencing reasonable success in the subsector. Road projects

funded by ADB are subject to cost overruns, but on the whole they have been built to high 
standards and through transparent procurement arrangements. Getting projects built on time, 
within  budget,  and  to  high  standards  is  possible  but  requires  innovative  approaches.  
The Railway Project started in 2010 is one of the fastest ever implemented by ADB. This was 
achieved  largely  on  account  of  four  actions:  (i)  outsourcing  of  the  supervision  function; 
(ii) reliable security arrangements during implementation; (iii) use of a fixed price, fixed delivery 
contract with premiums and penalties; and (iv) regular monitoring by ADB teams in Kabul and 
headquarters. A contract just awarded to complete the last 230 km of the Ring Road will follow a 
similar approach.  
6.  Strategic  context  and  roadmap.  The  Afghanistan  National  Development  Strategy 
(ANDS) represents the strategic framework for development between 2008–2020. The ANDS 
infrastructure pillar aims at establishing a safe and integrated network to ensure good domestic 
and international connectivity at a low cost. A roadmap for the sector identifies short, medium, 
and  long  term  investments  covering  roads,  rail,  and  airports. 5 This  roadmap  outlines  the 
sequencing of physical investments, actions, and reforms required to stimulate institutional 
effectiveness.  The  investment  requirement  up  to  2020  exceeds  $3  billion.6 ADB's  Country 
Partnership Strategy (CPS) for 2009–2013 is aligned with ANDS. The regional agenda figures 
prominently in the CPS and transport sector roadmap. Afghanistan is a transit country or “center 
of gravity” and is one of the most active members of the Central Asia Regional Economic 
Cooperation  (CAREC)  program.  Of  the  six  identified  CAREC  corridors,  three  traverse 
Afghanistan.  Recent  ADB  projects  in  the  transport  sector  have  been  funded  under  a 
multitranche  financing  facility  (MFF),  now  fully  utilized. 7 Supporting  new  priority  projects 
requires a new MFF. The strategy and roadmap underpinning the first MFF remains valid for 
this new MFF. 
7.  Policy framework. The transport sector benefits from a clear policy framework that 
outlines the vision and principles for investment, maintenance, institutional change and reform. 
It also outlines the need for better planning and oversight, cost recovery, and adherence to best 
practices on procurement, safety, governance as a whole, gender considerations, construction 
standards, and traffic management. Institutional effectiveness also includes a call for better 
budgeting and financial management, information systems to monitor performance, evaluation 
and reporting, and training of Afghans. The framework focuses on multimode systems.  
8.  New MFF. The government has requested ADB to provide a new MFF for financing 
priority road and rail projects over the next few years. The new MFF has more or less firm 
tranches (except for the first, each tranche is subject to final due diligence). These tranches are 
split between road and rail interventions. The MFF is the preferred funding modality given its 
flexibility and ability to sequence investments. All the preconditions for the MFF are in place, 
including the existence of a coherent strategy, sector roadmap, investment and financing plans, 
and  policy  framework.  The  new  MFF  amounts  to  $805  million.  This  will  consolidate  the 
partnership  started  under  the  existing  MFF.  Lessons  learned  from  past  operations  are 
incorporated  in  the  new  MFF  (footnote  4).  The  most  important  revolve  around  new 
implementation arrangements including the use of larger turnkey contracts, higher contractor 
and consultant quality, new contract modalities, independent project management, and regular 
ADB team involvement.

B.  Impact and Outcome 
9.  The impact of the investment program will be increased trade and jobs. The outcome will 
be increased movement of goods and services and better connectivity for people and businesses.  
C.  Outputs 
10.  The outputs include (i) about 578 km of reconstructed or rehabilitated regional and 
national roads, (ii) 225 km of constructed railway and stations between Mazar-e-Sharif and 
Andkhoy, (iii) efficient operation and maintenance (O&M) of the Hairatan to Mazar railway line, 
(iv) strengthened capacity at the Ministry of Public Works (MPW), and (v) improved transport 
sector governance.  
11.  The outputs under tranche 1 include 145 km of improved road sections: (i) 50 km 
between Bagramy–Sapary road, (ii) 51 km between Jabul Saraj–Nijrab, and (iii) 44 km between 
Faizabad–Beharak. Tranche 1 will also support the Railway Project O&M contract, including 
additional project facilities and equipment to ensure its efficiency. The capacity component will 
deliver a new governance needs assessment; a revised national road and rail transport plan; 
assistance to the rail authority and a detailed feasibility study and design work for the new 
Mazar-e-Sharif  to  Andkhoy  railway.  Other  outputs  include  special  assistance  to  improve 
planning  at  MPW; a  new  road  and  rail  asset  management system; procurement, financial 
management, safeguards plans; evaluation, monitoring and reporting and training.  
12.  Future tranches under the MFF are fairly firm. Tranche 2 will reconstruct the remaining 
106 km section of the Kabul to Jalalabad road, the remaining 112 km of the Faizabad to 
Eshkashem road, and 33 km of the Lashkar Gah to Gereshk road. Tranche 3 will construct the 
Mazar-e-Sharif to Andkhoy railway, and most likely reconstruct the first 101 km section of the 
Dar-i-Suf to Yakawlang road. Tranche 4 will reconstruct the remaining 81 km section of the Dar-
i-Suf to Yakawlang road. Each future tranche will also cater for capacity support, feasibility 
studies, and other “soft” investments.  
D.  Investment and Financing Plans 
1.  Investment Plan 
13.  Afghanistan’s  overall  road  and  rail  investment  plan  up  to  2020  exceeds  $3  billion.  
The rail network is the least complete and the most expensive ($2.5 billion). Remaining priority 
road investments run to $1 billion. The more medium term part of this plan (up to 2017) is 
estimated to cost $2.7 billion.  
14.  The investment program will cost $805 million equivalent. Subprojects financed under 
Tranche 1, including taxes, duties, and physical contingencies will cost $232 million equivalent. 
Table 1 summarizes the costs estimates and illustrates how the investment program fills a 
significant gap in Afghanistan’s overall land transport network development plans.

2.  Financing Plan 
15.  The broad road and rail investment plan needs ADB and other development partner 
assistance.  ADB  support  will  be  channeled  through  the  new  MFF  and  the  Afghanistan 
Infrastructure Trust Fund (AITF).  Although still evolving, two countries (Japan and the United 
Kingdom) have already contributed funding to the AITF. Others are considering doing the same. 
The MFF is being structured as follows: (i) up to $754 million from ADB’s Special Funds 
resources (the Asian Development Fund [ADF]), and (ii) a grant of $33 million from the AITF 
administered by ADB.8 Finance extended under the MFF will cover the business receipts tax 
(BRT).9 This is the practice also followed by the World Bank in Afghanistan.  
16.  Approval of finance under the MFF will be subject to the government’s submission of 
periodic financing requests (PFRs), execution of related grant and/or loan agreements for each 
tranche, and fulfillment of the terms and conditions and undertakings set out in the framework 
financing agreement (FFA). The government has been informed that the allocation of ADF 
resources is subject to (i) the availability of ADF resources from time to time, (ii) Afghanistan’s 
access  to  such  resources  pursuant  to  ADB’s  then  applicable  Graduation  Policy10 and  the 
requirements of ADF donors, and (iii) availability of such resources to Afghanistan pursuant to 
ADB’s then applicable policy on the performance based allocation of ADF resources11 and other

framework is determined by its risk to debt distress. The latest debt sustainability analysis 
determined a high risk of debt distress, making the country eligible to receive 100% of its ADF

program. It cannot be ruled out therefore that its eligibility for grant financing will not change.  
17.  Grant  financing  from  ADF  resources  will  be  made  available  under  the  Special 
Operations  Grant  Regulations  subject  to  any  modifications  in  the  grant  agreements.  
Loan financing from ADF resources will be made available under the Special Operations Loan 
Regulations subject to any modifications in the loan agreements. Grant financing from AITF will 
be  made  available  under  ADB’s  Externally  Financed  Grant  Regulations  subject  to  any 
modifications in the individual grant agreements. 
18.  Tranche 1 of the MFF amounts to $222 million and includes (i) a grant of $189 million 
from ADB’s Special Funds resources on terms and conditions set out in the Special Operations 
Grant Regulations and such other terms and conditions set forth in the related grant agreement 
(ADF grant), and (ii) a grant of $33 million from the AITF to be administered by ADB on terms 
set out in the Externally Financed Grant Regulations to finance the Bagramy–Sapary Road and 
additional financing for the Railway Project. The government will contribute $10 million for land 
acquisition. 
19.  The additional financing for the Railway Project covers works necessary to support 
various activities related to the operations and maintenance contract, including gap financing. In 
2011, the government concluded a three year performance-based O&M services contract with 
an affiliate of the Uzbekistan State Railway Company, SE Sogdiana Trans (O&M Contract).13 
Based on the O&M Contract terms and expected revenue yields,14 railway O&M is expected to 
become self-sustaining when the freight volume reaches 3.8 million tons per year. Volumes 
below this benchmark need a subsidy. The government requested ADB to provide $17 million 
over 3 years to meet part of the O&M financing gap.15 The scope of the Railway Project was 
changed in June 2011 to incorporate a new O&M component. It also applied $4 million in 
savings  under  the  project  to  help  finance  the  gap  during  the  first  year  of  operation.  The 
government requests that ADB provide additional financing of up to a further $13 million under 
tranche 1 of the MFF to help meet the expected financing gap. Separately, the government also 
requests a further $20 million under tranche 1 to cover some civil works, equipment, and 
inspection  services  needed  to  operate  the  railway.  The  request  complies  with  eligibility 
requirements for additional financing.16 Moreover, activities proposed for additional financing 
under tranche 1 are consistent with development objectives of the Railway Project. However, 
the policy currently applicable to MFFs restricts the use of MFF funds for additional finance to 
funding for “price or financing arrangement changes”.17 In this instance, it is proposed that

20.  ADB transport sector projects in Afghanistan have experienced regular cost overruns

provide additional financing to other ongoing ADB transport sector projects whenever these are 
consistent with eligibility requirements, existing ADB policies and procedures, the investment 
program and as agreed between the government and ADB.

E.  Implementation Arrangements 
21.  The  Ministry  of  Public  Works  (MPW)  will  be  the  executing  agency.  A  project 
management office (PMO) set up under the existing MFF will administer the program. A project 
implementation unit established within the PMO to implement the Railway Project will continue 
to oversee activities related to the railway. 
22.  The government will follow ADB’s policies and procedures, including the Procurement 
Guidelines (2010, as amended from time to time), Guidelines on the Use of Consultants by ADB 
and its Borrowers (2010, as amended from time to time) and the Loan Disbursement Handbook 
(2007,  as  amended  from  time  to  time).  The  government  requested  approval  of  retroactive 
financing  under  tranche  1  not  exceeding  20% of  the  aggregate  ADF grant  and  AITF grant 
amounts to cover eligible civil works, O&M equipment and consulting services. Two of the road

7 
subprojects included under tranche 119 were originally intended for inclusion in the second tranche 
of the existing MFF. However, following a reallocation of funds to complete the priority Ring Road, 
these investments were not funded under that tranche. The government proceeded with advance 
actions in the expectation that these subprojects would be covered later under the MFF. Since the 
MFF  does  not  have  any  unallocated  funding  left,  the  government  asked  ADB  to  approve 
retroactive financing under the new MFF to reimburse expenditures incurred up to 18 months 
before the signing date of the grant agreement.20 Given these circumstances, and as advance 
actions  have  facilitated  project  readiness  and  been  undertaken  in  accordance  with  ADB 
requirements, the request is considered justified, and thus proposed as part of the new MFF.  
23.  O&M services for the Railway Project financed under tranche 1 will be provided under 
the  existing  O&M  Contract.  Railway  O&M  equipment  will  be  procured  on  the  basis  of 
international  competitive  bidding.  Given  the  role  of  Uzbekistan  State  Railway  Company-
O’zbekistan Temir Yo’llari (UTY) as the engineering, procurement, and construction contractor 
for the Railway Project, UTY is proposed to be appointed on a direct contracting basis to 
undertake the ancillary civil and track works for additional financing under tranche 1.21 This will 
save considerable time and money. 
24.  Specific actions to ensure the efficient implementation of future projects under the MFF 
include (i) high state of readiness; (ii) large turnkey contract packages; (iii) fixed price and fixed 
delivery contracts with premiums and penalties against timelines and quality standards; and    
(iv) independent supervision with emphasis on in-house qualified staff for core jobs, quality, and 
dual reporting to ADB and MPW. The latter is fundamental. It aids ADB’s monitoring and 
reporting  and  facilitates  the  preparation  of  action  plans  to  correct  poor  performance.  
The consultants will be required to clear design proposals and payment requests against agreed 
contract  schedules.  Project  management  is  to  be  effectively  outsourced.  The  underlying 
premise  is  that  the  quality  of  the  implementation  depends  largely  on  the  quality  of  the 
contractors  and  consultants.    As  far  as  possible,  projects  will  follow  a  “design  and  build” 
approach. Each bid will be subject to special features to ensure competition, efficiency, and 
quality. All contracts will be subject to audits by independent external consultants.

III.  DUE DILIGENCE 
A.  Economic and Financial  
26.  Economic analysis was carried out for tranche 1. The economic analysis is conservative, 
focusing on the direct benefits generated from savings in vehicle operating costs and user time. 
Net economic benefits are expected to exceed the sum of individual project cost estimates. 
Based on the economic internal rate of return (EIRR), net present value (NPV), and sensitivity 
analysis, the subprojects under tranche 1 are feasible.  
B.  Governance  
27.  ADB’s Anticorruption Policy was explained to, and discussed with, the government and 
MPW. Specific policy requirements and supplementary measures are described in the facility 
administration manual. The government’s policies and procedures on financial management, 
procurement, anticorruption, and other institutional issues and mechanisms were found to be 
satisfactory.22 All  bidding  documents  for  contracts  under  the  MFF  will  include  provisions 
specifying ADB’s right to audit records and accounts related to the MFF, as well as those of all 
contractors, suppliers, consultants, and other service providers as they relate to the MFF. MPW 
and  the  Ministry  of  Finance  will  take  additional  measures  to  strengthen  governance, 
accountability, and transparency under the MFF, primarily with direct payment procedures. Key 
measures  are  (i) external  auditing  of  contracts,  project  accounts,  and financial  statements; 
(ii) transparent  decisions  on  all  procurement  matters;  and  (iii)  verification  of  contractors’ 
payment claims by supervision consultants following contract specifications. 
                                                
22 ADB and World Bank conducted risk assessments of country level systems in 2007 and 2009, respectively.

9 
C.  Poverty and Social 
28.  A  summary  poverty  reduction  and  social  strategy  was  prepared.  As  a  general 
intervention, the investment program is expected to generate both direct and indirect poverty 
reduction impacts. Expected benefits to road and rail users include lower travel times and cost, 
and in the case of roads, lower vehicle operating costs, which will result in higher product profit 
margins. Expanded access to improved roads and rail will help shift subsistence agriculture into 
a more market-based one, allowing farmers to grow commercial products that can be shipped to 
markets more quickly. Farmers may also diversify, cultivate high-value crops, and grow larger 
marketable surpluses to improve their income earning capacity. Connectivity will create more 
opportunities for people and businesses and widen access to social services. 
29.  A gender action framework was prepared to develop target activities to maximize the 
benefits for communities and women along the program roads and rail links. Increased access 
to social services, economic opportunity, and consumer choice is expected to significantly 
increase  the  welfare  of  women,  household  incomes,  achievement  of  the  Millennium 
Development Goals, and overall poverty reduction. 
D.  Safeguards  
30.  The impacts of tranche 1 on the environment, involuntary resettlement, and indigenous 
peoples were assessed in accordance with ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement (2009). MPW 
has prepared the required safeguards documents and mitigation measures in compliance with 
ADB  procedures  and  requirements  for  consultation  and  disclosure  to  the  public.  
The government has further illustrated its collective institutional capacity and commitment by 
increasing the number of qualified safeguards staff in the PMO and setting aside the funds 
required for land acquisition. 
31.  MPW prepared an environmental assessment and review framework, which sets out a 
framework for screening, categorization, impact assessment, management and monitoring for 
the investment program. Tranche 1 subprojects are unlikely to result in significant adverse 
environmental  impact  and  potential  impacts  can  be  adequately  monitored  and  mitigated. 
Therefore, they are classified as environment category B. An initial environmental examination 
incorporating an environmental management and monitoring plan was prepared for each of the 
three road sections included in tranche 1. The new Railway Project investments have minimal or 
no adverse environmental impacts and are classified as category C.  
32.  MPW  prepared  a  land  acquisition  and  resettlement  framework  for  the  investment 
program. Land acquisition and resettlement plans were prepared for each of the three road 
sections in tranche 1. The interventions are considered to be significant and are classified as 
category  A  for  involuntary  resettlement.  Following  approval,  these  land  acquisition  and 
resettlement plans were disclosed to the public on 19 July 2011. The government will finance 
land acquisition and ADB the associated resettlement costs. Changes to the Railway Project 
have no involuntary resettlement impacts and therefore are classified as category C. No people 
who can be defined as indigenous are in the project areas. As such, the indigenous people’s 
classification is category C, and indigenous peoples safeguard measures are not required.  
E.  Risks and Mitigating Measures 
33.  Major risks and mitigating measures are described in detail in the risk management plan. 
The main risks include (i) implementation delays, and (ii) sustainability and reforms. Security 
also remains an underlying concern for all work performed in Afghanistan.

10   
Table 4: Summary of Risks and Mitigating Measures 
Risks  Mitigating Measures 
Security  The  Ministry  of  Interior  will  provide  security  to  all  projects.  A  methodology  has  been 
established from past projects, with successful results.  
Readiness  Project  readiness  will  be  increased  through  advancing  design  work,  safeguards  plans, 
procurement of goods, works and services, funding for land acquisition and all internal 
approvals prior to ADB approving new tranches. Readiness will eliminate or reduce delays.  
Sustainability  Funding will be set aside for operations and maintenance. Planning will be improved, as well 
as budgeting, financial management, monitoring, evaluation and reporting. Reforms will be 
accelerated, including those leading to greater institutional effectiveness.  New approaches for 
project management will be put in place, including outsourcing of supervision and monitoring.   
ADB = Asian Development Bank, MPW = Ministry of Public Works, PMO = program management office.  
Sources: Asian Development Bank and Ministry of Public Works of Afghanistan. 
 
IV.  UNDERTAKINGS AND ASSURANCES  
34.  The  government  and  MPW  have  assured  ADB  that  implementing  the  investment 
program will conform to all applicable ADB policies including those concerning anticorruption 
measures, safeguards, gender, procurement, consulting services, and disbursement as detailed 
in the facility administration manual and grant and/or loan documents. 
35.  The government has given ADB certain undertakings for the MFF, as described in the 
FFA. Specific covenants agreed to by the government and MPW, with respect to individual 
tranches under the MFF, are set forth in the grant and/or loan agreements for the respective 
tranches.  
V.  RECOMMENDATION  
36.  I am satisfied that the proposed multitranche financing facility would comply with the 
Articles of Agreement of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) and recommend that the Board 
approve the provision of loans or grants and the administration of grants under the multitranche 
financing  facility  in  an  aggregate  principal  amount  not  exceeding  $787,000,000  equivalent 
(facility amount) to the Islamic Republic of Afghanistan for the Transport Network Development 
Investment Program comprising:  
(i)  loans in various currencies or grants in an aggregate principal amount up to 
$754,000,000 equivalent from ADB’s Special Funds resources, with terms to be 
determined in accordance with ADB’s then applicable policies relating to Special 
Funds resources; and  
(ii)  grants in an aggregate amount not exceeding the balance of the facility amount 
from the Afghanistan Infrastructure Trust Fund, with terms to be determined in 
accordance  with  ADB’s  then  applicable  policies  relating  to  the  Afghanistan 
Infrastructure Trust Fund, 
subject to conditions set forth in paragraphs 16 and 17 of this report and such other terms and 
conditions as are substantially in accordance with those set forth in the framework financing 
agreement presented to the Board.  
37.  I  also  recommend  that  the  Board  approve  a  deviation  from  the  existing  policy  as 
discussed in paragraph 19 of this report to allow the first tranche of the multitranche financing 
facility to provide additional financing for the Hairatan to Mazar-e-Sharif Railway Project.
